title: Autoimmune Dementia / Encephalopathy
icd10: G13.1 (Other systemic atrophy primarily affecting CNS in neoplastic disease — paraneoplastic limbic encephalitis)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of autoimmune-mediated cognitive decline and encephalopathy. This is a "must-not-miss" diagnosis — autoimmune dementia is one of the few truly treatable and potentially reversible causes of dementia and rapidly progressive cognitive decline. Covers antibody-mediated encephalitis (NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2, AMPAR, GABA-B, DPPX), paraneoplastic limbic encephalitis, and seronegative autoimmune encephalopathy. Includes rapid diagnostic workup, empiric immunotherapy, cancer screening, and long-term maintenance. Applies to all clinical settings.

— Core Labs (Order for All Patients).rationale: Hepatic, renal, electrolyte, glucose — exclude metabolic encephalopathy
Thyroid disease; also needed for SREAT workup
SREAT/Hashimoto encephalopathy — elevated in ~85% of cases; but also elevated in ~10% of general population (low specificity)
Second thyroid antibody for SREAT — increases sensitivity
Inflammatory marker; elevated in vasculitis, systemic autoimmune, infection
Exclude B12 deficiency — treatable cause of cognitive decline
Neurosyphilis — must rule out in RPD workup

— Extended Labs — Autoimmune and Paraneo.rationale: **Critical** — NMDA-R Ab, LGI1 Ab, CASPR2 Ab, AMPA-R Ab, GABA-B Ab, DPPX Ab; send to reference lab (Mayo, Quest Autoimmune); results take 1-3 weeks — **do NOT wait for results to start empiric immunotherapy if clinical suspicion is high**
**Essential — more sensitive than serum for NMDAR antibodies** (serum can be negative with positive CSF in up to 14%); CSF should be sent simultaneously with serum; also include GABA-A, IgLON5
Lymphocytic pleocytosis (WBC 5-100, predominantly lymphocytes) supports autoimmune encephalitis; elevated protein common; glucose usually normal (vs infectious meningitis)
Intrathecal IgG synthesis — supports CNS autoimmune process; also evaluate for MS
Lymphomatous meningitis, carcinomatous meningitis — on RPD differential
**Prion disease exclusion** — 14-3-3 sensitivity ~85% for CJD; RT-QuIC sensitivity >90%, specificity >99%; total tau >1150 pg/mL highly suggestive of CJD
ANNA-1 (Hu), ANNA-2, PCA-1 (Yo), PCA-2, PCA-Tr (DNER), CV2/CRMP5, Ma2/Ta, amphiphysin, GAD65 (high titer >20 nmol/L)

— Rare/Specialized Labs.rationale: AD biomarkers — low Aβ42/high p-tau suggests neurodegenerative, not autoimmune; useful to differentiate
Whipple disease — rare but treatable cause of RPD
IgLON5 disease — sleep disorder, cognitive decline, brainstem dysfunction; unique tauopathy
Autoimmune GFAP astrocytopathy — meningoencephalitis, often with perivascular pattern on MRI

— Essential Imaging.item: MRI brain with/without contrast (thin-cut temporal, FLAIR, DWI, T2, post-gad)
— Essential Imaging.rationale: **First-line and most important imaging** — T2/FLAIR hyperintensity in mesial temporal lobes (hippocampus, amygdala) is classic for limbic encephalitis; DWI cortical ribboning suggests CJD; enhancement patterns vary by antibody type; may be normal in up to 30% of autoimmune encephalitis
Seizures (often subclinical), extreme delta brush (pathognomonic for anti-NMDAR encephalitis), periodic discharges (CJD), diffuse slowing (encephalopathy); continuous EEG in ICU patients
Rapid screening in ED to exclude mass, hemorrhage, hydrocephalus; MRI is ultimately needed
Malignancy screening (lung cancer — Hu, CRMP5); infection

— Extended Imaging — Cancer Screening.rationale: Comprehensive cancer screening — lung (SCLC → Hu, CRMP5, AMPAR), ovarian teratoma (NMDAR), thymoma (CASPR2, LGI1), lymphoma, renal
Ovarian teratoma screening — **mandatory in anti-NMDAR encephalitis** in women; teratoma removal is therapeutic; may require MRI pelvis if US inconclusive
Testicular tumor screening in young males with anti-NMDAR or Ma2 antibodies
Most sensitive for occult malignancy when CT is negative; particularly useful for paraneoplastic antibodies with intracellular targets (Hu, Yo, Ma2)
If ovarian teratoma suspected but US inconclusive
If amphiphysin antibody positive — associated with breast cancer

— Rare/Specialized Studies.rationale: Hypermetabolism in medial temporal lobes (limbic encephalitis) vs hypometabolism (neurodegenerative); can be positive when MRI is normal
Last resort — only if all other investigations negative and progressive decline; rule out CNS vasculitis, lymphoma, CJD; high morbidity; should target area of abnormality on MRI
If primary CNS vasculitis suspected (beading pattern); can be normal in small vessel vasculitis
Document cognitive profile, track treatment response, differentiate from neurodegenerative patterns; LGI1 typically limbic (amnesia); NMDAR often frontal-subcortical

— Acute / First-Line Immunotherapy.indication: First-line acute immunotherapy; often combined with IVIG or PLEX

dosing.instructions: infuse over 1 hour; premedicate with famotidine

— Acute / First-Line Immunotherapy.contraindications: Avoid if CJD is the primary concern (steroids do not help and delay diagnosis)
— Acute / First-Line Immunotherapy.monitoring: Glucose (hyperglycemia), blood pressure, insomnia, psychiatric side effects

— Acute / First-Line Immunotherapy.indication: First-line acute immunotherapy; often combined with steroids; preferred over PLEX in many centers due to ease of administration

dosing.instructions: infuse per protocol (total 2 g/kg divided over 5 days); premedicate with acetaminophen, diphenhydramine

— Acute / First-Line Immunotherapy.contraindications: IgA deficiency (anaphylaxis risk — check IgA level before first dose); thrombosis risk
— Acute / First-Line Immunotherapy.monitoring: Infusion reactions, IgA level before first dose

— Acute / First-Line Immunotherapy.indication: First-line alternative to IVIG; preferred in severe/ICU cases; more rapid antibody clearance

dosing.instructions: total 1-1.5 plasma volumes per session; requires central venous access

— Acute / First-Line Immunotherapy.monitoring: Hypotension, electrolyte imbalance, coagulopathy, line infection

— Second-Line Immunotherapy (If First-Li.indication: First-choice second-line agent; anti-CD20 B-cell depletion; effective in NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2, and many other antibody-mediated encephalitides

dosing.instructions: or 1000 mg IV x 2 doses 2 weeks apart; pre-treat with methylprednisolone 100 mg IV, acetaminophen, diphenhydramine

— Second-Line Immunotherapy (If First-Li.contraindications: Hepatitis B (reactivation risk — screen before starting); PML risk (rare)
— Second-Line Immunotherapy (If First-Li.monitoring: Onset of action 2-4 weeks; hepatitis B serology before starting

— Second-Line Immunotherapy (If First-Li.indication: Second-choice second-line; used with rituximab in severe refractory anti-NMDAR encephalitis

dosing.instructions: with MESNA and aggressive hydration

— Second-Line Immunotherapy (If First-Li.contraindications: Significant toxicity: hemorrhagic cystitis, infertility, secondary malignancy
— Second-Line Immunotherapy (If First-Li.monitoring: CBC weekly during treatment; myelosuppression monitoring

— Maintenance Immunotherapy (Relapse Pre.indication: Oral steroid bridge after IV pulse; long-term maintenance in relapse-prone patients

dosing.instructions: taper by 10 mg/week to 20 mg, then 5 mg/week to off; or maintain 10-20 mg daily long-term if relapse-prone

— Maintenance Immunotherapy (Relapse Pre.monitoring: Cushingoid effects, osteoporosis (start calcium + vitamin D), hyperglycemia, cataracts

— Maintenance Immunotherapy (Relapse Pre.indication: Steroid-sparing maintenance; commonly used for LGI1, CASPR2, autoimmune encephalitis relapse prevention

dosing.instructions: start 500 mg BID, increase to 1000 mg BID over 2-4 weeks
start 50 mg daily, titrate up over 4-6 weeks

— Maintenance Immunotherapy (Relapse Pre.contraindications: Poor TPMT metabolizers at risk for severe myelosuppression (check TPMT genotype before starting)
— Maintenance Immunotherapy (Relapse Pre.monitoring: CBC, LFTs; onset of action 3-6 months

— Maintenance Immunotherapy (Relapse Pre.indication: Long-term B-cell depletion for relapsing autoimmune encephalitis

dosing.instructions: or guided by CD19/CD20 B-cell reconstitution

— Maintenance Immunotherapy (Relapse Pre.contraindications: Infection risk; hypogammaglobulinemia with repeated cycles

— Tumor Treatment (Paraneoplastic Cases).indication: Essential in all paraneoplastic cases; neurologic improvement is unlikely without tumor treatment

dosing.instructions: Ovarian teratoma removal (anti-NMDAR); SCLC treatment (chemo/radiation); thymectomy for thymoma-associated cases

— Tumor Treatment (Paraneoplastic Cases).monitoring: Post-operative neurologic status; antibody titers post-resection

— Tumor Treatment (Paraneoplastic Cases).indication: Paraneoplastic antibodies confirmed but initial screening negative; occult tumors may emerge later

dosing.instructions: Repeat imaging at 3-6 month intervals for up to 5 years

— Tumor Treatment (Paraneoplastic Cases).monitoring: Serial imaging (CT, PET/CT) per cancer surveillance schedule

— Seizure Management.indication: First-line ASM for autoimmune encephalitis seizures; minimal drug interactions

— Referrals.rationale: Specialized management of autoimmune encephalitis; immunotherapy selection and monitoring; long-term relapse prevention
All paraneoplastic cases — tumor staging, treatment planning; gynecologic oncology for teratoma
Refractory seizures, continuous EEG interpretation, ASM optimization
Psychiatric manifestations (especially NMDAR encephalitis — frequently misdiagnosed as primary psychiatric illness); capacity evaluation
Baseline and follow-up cognitive testing to document treatment response
Cognitive rehabilitation, motor recovery, speech/swallowing if affected
Insurance navigation (IVIG/rituximab are expensive — prior authorization), disability applications, caregiver support
